headline: CNN 10
subHeadline: Combating AI-generated Content Ahead Of The U.S. Election; "Urban Surfers" Rummaging For Recyclable Plastics In South Africa; Baby Giraffe, Kendi, At The Oakland Zoo. Aired 4-4:10a ET

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Ten second trivia.How many water bottles are sold every minute around the world? A thousand, 10,000, 100,000 or 1 million? If you guess 1 million, you are correct. And that number`s expected to nearly double by the year 2030, the U.N. says this is helping to perpetuate a worldwide plastic pollution crisis. The U.N. says that more than 90% of single use plastic is produced from fossil fuels or unrecycled material. Well, in South Africa, these urban surfers rise before dawn, ravaging through bins and household waste for recyclable materials and are actually helping the African country become one of the best recycling nations on earth. Our David McKenzie reports on how their work has an important environmental impact for our climate. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) DAVID MCKENZIE, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): Tlamoke Mokoka and his cart are on the move. His job goes by many names here. Reclaimer. Hustler. Even Urban Surfer. It`s dangerous work in a dangerous city. There are thousands like Mokoka fanning out well before dawn. After an hour on the road, he`s in a neighborhood south of the city.

utterances.speaker: TLAMOKE MOKOKA, RECYCLING RECLAIMER
utterances.sentences: I`m looking for the plastics.MCKENZIE (voice-over): I`m looking for plastics, cardboard boxes, metals, and cans, he says.

utterances.speaker: MOKOKA
utterances.sentences: Metals.

utterances.speaker: MCKENZIE
utterances.sentences: And it`s a dirty job, do you mind?

utterances.speaker: MOKOKA
utterances.sentences: I don`t mind.MCKENZIE (voice-over): What they discard, he recycles, earning about $150 a month. It`s steadier than his old construction job, and Mokoka likes being his own boss. There aren`t any jobs here, he says, so we`ve made our own work, making their own work with a scale and impact that`s hard to overstate. Just look at this sorting zone near Joburg where thousands live. It`s informal but hardly simple. Everything is carefully separated. Everything has value. (On camera): Towards the top of the pecking order are cans. Now, a bag of these will get reclaimers almost 40 U.S. dollars. As they say, one man`s trash is another man`s treasure. (Voice-over): I`m always surprised how rich people throw away so much rubbish, says Tlakatla Khang, but I`m happy they do. This collection took them weeks. I don`t know much about climate change, he says. Of course I`m glad we can help, but what matters is to survive. Today is payday and every bag is carefully weighed. There`s always trust amongst us, says middleman Motsama. Though he seems a little skeptical. I have to double check they didn`t put any water in the bottles to make them heavier, he says. It must just be the plastic bottles. What reclaimers don`t find end up in a nearby landfill. Even here, the desperate salvage what they can. Back in the neighborhoods, Mokoka`s in a race against the dump trucks.

utterances.speaker: MOKOKA
utterances.sentences: Done, we have done, done.

utterances.speaker: MCKENZIE
utterances.sentences: Are you done?

utterances.speaker: MOKOKA
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: MCKENZIE
utterances.sentences: Just in time.

utterances.speaker: MOKOKA
utterances.sentences: Yeah.MCKENZIE (voice-over): Today, they arrived a bit late.

utterances.speaker: MOKOKA
utterances.sentences: I have more stuff today, man.

utterances.speaker: MCKENZIE
utterances.sentences: More stuff?

utterances.speaker: MOKOKA
utterances.sentences: More stuff than other days.MCKENZIE (voice-over): Mokoka is proud of his work, proud of his effort.

utterances.speaker: MOKOKA
utterances.sentences: Yeah, I feel so happy.MCKENZIE (voice-over): I feel so happy, I feel so happy, he says, because I`m going to put bread on the table. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: At the Oakland Zoo, a six-week-old baby giraffe named Kendi is learning to stand on her long spaghetti noodle legs. And she`s looking todrink water from remote, but she hasn`t quite got her foot just yet. Today, our 10 out of 10 goes to Kendi where her adorable tent in drinking water has not hindered her from running and kicking like a champ. Our Jeanne Moos has more. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: JEANNE MOOS, CNN NATIONAL NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: The Oakland Zoo`s baby giraffe almost has her sea legs. This is one of her last hurdles to drinkfrom the motte.

utterances.speaker: AMY PHELPS, ZOOLOGICAL MANAGER, OAKLAND ZOO
utterances.sentences: They have to spread their front feet sort of like a V.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: Almost, almost, but not quite, still this six-week-old giraffe named Kendi has come a long way fast. Even when she was still inside mom`s belly.Those legs were kicking. Watch her kick again, but it doesn`t hurt mom.

utterances.speaker: PHELPS
utterances.sentences: They have what we call angel slippers, which is just a soft coating that goes over their hooves.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: Like gummy candy that comes off after the baby exits, Kendi actually stood up for the first time. The same day she was born.

utterances.speaker: PHELPS
utterances.sentences: They`re kind of like their maid of spaghetti noodles at first.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: But they learned to stand quickly to escape predators. She already runs like a champ and has even started kicking.

utterances.speaker: PHELPS
utterances.sentences: So they have the ability to kick in all four directions at the same time, with all four legs.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: You can watch Kendi`s progress on the zoo`s live webcam. She may still have trouble reaching the ground to drink. Her legs may look spindly,but they`re flexible and bendy.

utterances.speaker: PHELPS
utterances.sentences: In some ways they`re very much like little yoga masters.(END VIDEOTAPE)
